pros: Generally, the folks who do the work are amazing, driven, smart, talented people. The insurance and PTO benefits are actually very good. It's easy to convince yourself to stay through all the chaos and poor management when your colleagues become your friends. The work that we did in our department really is top of the line, award winning work and it was great being a part of that team.
cons: Leadership is unfortunately tone deaf, unhelpful, condescending, distrustful, and treats employees more like children than professional adults. I have countless stories I could share, but quite frankly I gave everything to my department trying to make it better, get a solid process in place, and create a decent work environment to no avail. No matter how many times myself and others brought up issues, asked for a process to be implemented, or tried to incite change, it was always glazed over or ignored by upper management. Some of us even went so far as to raise issues to HR who simply stated they couldn't get involved in departmental affairs. Everyone is aware of the issues, from group managers to the VP of the department and yet somehow they're still ok with watching amazing employees walk out the door instead of doing everything they can to have them stay. When I left there was essentially a full new team from when I started five years earlier because the turnover is so aggressive. There was no effort made for retention, many of the people who left would have stayed if offered pay raises, promotions, or the issues of the job were addressed. Pay is below average. The only reason I ever got a raise outside of the yearly 2-3% "merit" raise is because I had been offered a job elsewhere and was going to take it unless BU could match the offer monetarily. Also, the only reason why work from home was even a consideration was because of the pandemic. Most employees live outside of the city and even though BU is flexible, this seems to be a pain point that can't be properly addressed at a University level. By the time I left I was burnt out. I lost my passion for my craft and I felt drained by BU. The hardest part was leaving my colleagues who became my friends.

pros: Loved my direct colleagues and the broader group of people I worked with, many benefits are top notch especially vacation time. Working with the students very fulfilling and rewarding. Tuition remission huge plus and honestly the way they attract most talent.
cons: Very little room for growth in student services, low pay, huge salary discrepancies between units as well as between student service staff and admins (the latter making much more than the former). No incentive to do well - professional development viewed as an annoyance by management and taking initiative isn't rewarded. HR is unhelpful and inefficient. Also was discouraged by the worst employees getting the same raises as the best, creating environment of mediocrity. All in all, only a long term place to stay if you want to punch in and punch out. No staff maternity leave means lots of women leave, often the best.

review_title: IT Organization is a low energy and overworked environment
pros: The benefits at a University such as BU are great.  Many vacation and sick days, and for full-time permanent employees, the tuition reimbursement can't be beat.  Unfortunately,  these perks are also why so many hang on even when the job isn't the best fit or they're unhappy.
cons: Majority of peers in the IT environment are overworked, overwhelmed and burnt out. It is not a highly engaged workplace and the culture is one that is low energy and depressing.  Staff are not valued as highly as they should be.  There are often not enough resources to do the work and management expects too much.  Many employees have a self protective attitude or "cya" as they fear failure and management.

pros: Excellent benefits package, including 4 weeks of vacation when you start (plus a week off between Christmas & New Years), and the most generous retirement plan I've seen anywhere (complicated formula, and the specifics are in the process of changing, but essentially they match at 2-3x the employee's contribution).  Workplace environment will vary wildly depending on which department you're in; mine gives me an extremely high degree of freedom, autonomy, and flexibility.
cons: You can't spell "bureaucracy" without "BU".  Offices such as HR, purchasing, payroll, IT, etc can be infuriatingly opaque and inflexible to deal with for even very simple transactions.  Salaries are not as generous as in the private sector.  Opportunities for advancement may be limited, as there is a tendency to fill even low-level management positions from outside hires instead of promoting internally.

review_title: Steady job with room for advancement and benefits improvement
pros: Working in a non-profit educational environment where knowledge is always flowing is always stimulating. Students are the life-blood of campus and bring a good energy to staffs' days. The job is consistent and reliable, and summertime is a more laid-back time of year at the university.
cons:
Unfortunately, career ladders don't yet exist at the college where I work, and employee recognition and advancement opportunities needs improvement. Title changes and promotions rarely occur, and many of my peers have needed to leave their offices or the institution as a whole in order to advance.

Also, Boston University is behind its university peers in parental support policies. For example, prior to the enactment of the new Massachusetts Family and Medical Leave Law, BU provided no paid bonding time leave for new parents. For example, if a new adoptive parent sought bonding time, they would need to use vacation time in order to get paid during that time away from work. While BU vacation time is generous, it's not generous enough to work well in this policy. New mother recovery time (from birth events) pay came from sick pay, rather than a separate designation.

pros:
Note this is all for being an summer RA at Boston University Tanglewood Institute

-Managers were a part of the residential life community, many of them had been RAs or even students there
-Fellow RAs were very friendly and welcoming, and I could count on them to help me out in a pinch
-We all had plenty of time off, since our on-call shifts were long and could be stressful 
-Good compensation for a summer job for college students, especially since they provided room and board
-Having passes to Tanglewood is an amazing perk, particularly if you enjoy classical music
cons: -Since we were in a small town, there's not a lot to do with your time off - I'd recommend having a time-off project (like reading a book series or teaching yourself a new skill) to make sure you don't get bored.

review_title: Fun place to work; decent way to supplement your income; look for long-term career opportunities elsewhere.
pros: Coworkers are fun, the students (customers) are hungry for new knowledge and skills development, and the freedom to manage your own work without undue oversight and micromanagement.
cons: As a contract worker don't expect to ever have a department head enter into a dialog about your performance -- or ever receive an increase in compensation for delivering results.

review_title: Great place to get a (nearly free!) advanced degree while you are working
pros: I came to BU largely because of their generous tuition remission benefit; I earned my masters' degree in 12 months and BU paid about 90% of the cost. It's a great place in the sense that there are tons of formal and informal learning opportunities--lectures, concerts, symposiums, professional trainings, classes with tuition remission, etc. In my personal experience (though this is not necessarily the norm in all depts), my boss is great--smart, available, fair, and encouraging.
cons: After almost three years, I'm ready for a new challenge; and although I have my masters now and have been applying to new jobs within BU for about 10 months, I've only had 3 internal interviews and no offers. HR throws around the message  that "BU wants to recognize and promote from within", but that has absolutely not been my experience--and it's extremely frustrating.

review_title: Management is incompetent, and very frustrating to deal with.
job_title: Senior Safety Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Decent pay. Good location. Good benefits, including tuition remission. Proximity to downtown Boston is a plus. Access to gym and intramural sports.
cons: Most managers are incompetent. High turnover.  Management is less knowledgeable than rank and file, yet take credit for direct reports work. Culture of blame is rampant. Very minimal training, of which is mostly sub-par. No real path for growth within the department of EHS.

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Boston, MA
pros: Working as a writing tutor has allowed me to meet with other great writers across different disciplines. Helping my fellow students with their writing also gave me a better understanding of my own writing. My boss is very easy-going. In short, I love working with my colleagues, and I love helping other people with their writing.
cons: Students sometimes get different messages from professors and us writing tutors, which occasionally generate misunderstanding. Professors want students to go to writing center and let us help them with grammar and other basic building blocks in terms of writing, but our goal as writing tutors is to help them become better writers, not editing.

job_title: Lead Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros:
* Reasonably good work/life balance
* Good retirement savings benefits
* Interesting cultural life, if you choose to engage in it (theater, lecture series, sports)
* Tuition remission is a HUGE benefit if you want to earn a degree, or your kids might go to BU
* I really love my boss, and enjoy working in my department (IT)
cons:
* BU is such a big employer that your experience can vary a LOT depending on who your boss is, and what your department does. This isn't necessarily a "Con," but rather just something to keep in mind when applying for jobs here
* Our health insurance plans aren't that great. Deductibles are high, as are out-of-pocket maximum. You can reduce your costs if you use providers at Boston Medical Center, but that's not convenient for everybody
* Opportunities for career advancement vary widely depending on where you are. People tend to stick around for a long time, so sometimes key positions don't turn over for a decade or longer.

review_title: Great for entry level...but not for the long haul
job_title: International Student Advisor in Boston, MA
pros: Lots of opportunities as it is a big campus, classes, gym, events. Opportunity for continuing education is great as they supplement tuition significantly.  Coworkers are the best and overall they hire excellent people.   Decent benefits package, althought short term disability could be better.
cons: Large campus = lot so burocracy  so sometimes it is hard to accomplish a task that has long standing change/benefits.  Pay is usually slightly below market.  Can b hard to advance.  Sometimes  felt like the work-life balance wasn't appreciated.  Often made to feel that using our significant vacation time that came as part of our benefits package was a burden on the office. Quick to deduct 15 min of sick time if you had a morning dr. appt and came in 15 min late, regardless of if you were salaried, worked late, didn't take lunch.

review_title: BU is a good destination for a postdoc
pros: Because BU is not Harvard or MIT, it tends to be a little more low key.  This is a bit of a double-edged sword.  Being a grad student, you definitely sense a bit of the inferiority complex, but at the same time, it's not nearly as cutthroat and allows you a little more freedom to live life outside of the lab.  And being in Boston has it's perks both socially and academically.  There are great resources in this town and ample opportunity for collaboration.  For a postdoc position it would be a good place interact with a vibrant scientific community without a lot of the insane academic rivarly that might come with some other places.
cons: It's not Harvard or MIT

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
Very good faculty members. They are all very talented and smart people, and they are all very nice. You can talk to any faculty member about physics, research, or any topic. Moreover, they are all very responsible people, and doing great researches themselves.

For the student community, all are very clever and love physics. Always talk to each other academically. Besides, grad students here like to have fun, so you can expect a lot of activities organized by students.

Physics department frequently invites speakers from other institutions or universities to give presentations, which is very helpful to broaden the perspective of knowledge.
cons: There are not much free food in the department. The office for grad students who do not have advisors have no windows.

review_title: Great for graduate level education, but not professional growth
pros: With full-time employment there are benefits, like an almost free education, full benefits and retirement.
cons: Very little growth opportunities for professionals who do not have a doctorate degree.  Very little innovation at the staff level.  Very little support and professional development of staff.  Many offices have staff who have been here for years, and are not invested in efficiency or high-quality work.  Hard to communicate across the Charles River Campus and the Medical Campus.  Work-life balance varies depending on the office and supervisors that you have.  Systems are disorganized and staff feedback on failing systems is often not heard.

job_title: Assistant Front Office Manager in Boston, MA
pros:
Pay Okay
Peers Okay
Travel Okay
Location Okay
Benefits great
cons: Most of Management is okay, there are exceptions, which made it a very unpleasant place to work.  One in particular is located at the Hariri Institute, she made life a living hell there, up until the time we were put under her umbrella working there was great. Sad, because there were several of us that were extremely good at our jobs, but while under her command our performance rapidly declined because of her terrible management skills.

job_title: Service Desk Student Employee in Boston, MA
pros: Working at the BU IT Help Center is a decent student job. They are very flexible with scheduling and most of the staff members you interact with are pleasant.
cons: Within the past year many of the full time staff members have left the Service Desk division of the ITHC with almost no new hires. Because of this the quality of service has gone down, and the students are the first ones to hear about it when someone calls in because they are getting horrible service. Its really frustrating to get yelled at every third time you pick up the phone, especially when you know the person on the other end is perfectly justified in being frustrated with the sub-par level of service.

pros: Very prepared and professional professors. Pressure is not unbearable (although it depends on your supervisor, so ask his students before joining the lab!). Lots of opportunity for meeting world-class professor, and build relationships that will be very useful for your post-doc or entry-level job. Conveniently located just steps away from Kenmore Square.
cons:
Obviously Boston University is not at the level of Harvard and MIT, but how many universities are?
The B line (subway to get to BU from the Allston/Brighton area) is terrible, crowded and extremely slow. So, if you live there, you might want to walk or bike to school. 
Administrative offices can be a bit messy, but if there is a problem usually things get sorted out.

review_title: Great benefits, some of the people suck
pros: Tuition Remission is the best benefit for working at any university, take classes for less than a hundred dollars (they still charge you for lab fees and the taxes of the class). The health insurance is also pretty good. You get all the of the national holidays off and winter session (12/23 - 1/2) paid time off.
cons: Many people at BU are elitist and kind of racist. They care about where you come from and where you got your degree from. Not so much the staff members but the faculty are coddled and don't know how to do much for themselves .

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Boston, MA
pros:
- Good experience 
- Good working environment if you get placed with a good professor
cons:
- Pay is limiting. You're not allowed to work any additional jobs. Making $20K and ONLY $20K in Boston is pretty low pay considering cost of living. This makes it hard to finish the academic program and a number of people have dropped out of my PhD program because of it.
- Restrictions on not being able to work mean grad students no longer have the opportunity to teach their own courses at MET or other universities. This is seriously hurting graduates' abilities to secure jobs. In my field you HAVE to have teaching experience and now we are no longer allowed to get that.
- Long hours when grading

pros: Depending on the department you work in, in my case it was a very small part in Creative Services, BU's offices seem to be very organized. There seems to be a person for every task - that I have seen. They had the right resources and the manpower to do the work.
cons: There are so many people work for BU, and you work to serve an institution so it's easy to feel like a small person within a huge organization. Moreover, you have to look out for yourself to get further in whatever field you are in. I did not learn many new things, but I simultaneously practiced my existing skills - I had the chance to learn some things on my own for the job.

pros: The Tuition Remission beneift is the best thing about working at BU. You get 4 credits free and then 4 more credits at 90% off each academic year. Also it's pretty easy to transfer between departments.
cons:
The beaurocracy of working at this institution is unbelievable. There is not an easy way to navigate any system. HR, Sourcing & Procurement, etc,

There is very little opportunity for upward mobility and someone else in your position in a different department could easily be getting paid up to twice what you do.

pros: Tuition benefits are excellent, salary is average, centrally located in Boston, most people are friendly and willing to help a new employee, opportunity to transfer between departments, benefits are ok as long as you are fine with using the BU medical and dental centers.
cons: Bureaucracy is sometimes difficult to get through, very high turnover, many (not all) departments do not actively promote from within, professional development opportunities are limited, HR department is difficult to work with as the individual case load in that office is huge.

review_title: Great 9-5, but no one's dream job
job_title: Enrollment Service Advisor in Boston, MA
pros:
For a large organization, BU does fairly well on issues of LGBTQ+, gender, and racial equality.
Salary grades help with pay equity, especially at entry level
Lots of room to move up within the university
Very little competition or hostility between employees
Tuition remission
cons:
Many people are there to do the minimum it takes to get through their 9-5 and go home.
Lower salary than most Boston-area colleges.
The university is huge, so it's hard to do anything unorthodox. Lots of bureaucratic hoops to jump through, as well. 
High turnover means regular chances for promotion, but also that a lot of people don't know how to do their jobs. 
Very little leadership training for management.

review_title: PhD Candidate in College of Engineering
job_title: PhD Candidate In College of Engineering in Boston, MA
pros: BU Engineering is a great place to explore interdisciplinary work, especially in photonics, biomedical engineering, and data science. It's a research university so as a PhD candidate you will be expected to contribute to publications, conference presentations, etc. But the faculty is top-tier, for example often collaborating with colleagues from MIT, Harvard, and other great schools.
cons: Focus on research makes graduate courses a little more self-driven. Students are presented with the material, but taking a deep dive is really up to the student / advisor, whether or not the material is relevant for research. So it takes effort to learn outside your area of expertise.

pros: When working full-time at Boston University, you receive tuition remission benefits that allow you to take free to discounted courses that further your education.  I am in a part-time Master's program that allows me to pursue this advanced degree for basically no cost.  Lots of student interaction, and most staff are enthusiastic and want to assist with professional development.
cons: It can be difficult to work within a bureaucratic system at times, but I have found that leadership and upper management work really hard to serve both the staff and the students in the best way they can.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: I'm writing this from my experience as a grad student for 5 years in BU ECE (so obviously this is my experience and might not be generalized). I have found BU to be great in providing all required resources for research, whether infrastructure, IT or facilities. Health-care benefits are competitive (although eye-care and dental care should be added). Great job-search resources as well. Professional conduct by all employees, Live at the heart of the city with MIT, Harvard and other major universities and hospitals around which leads to a vibrant academic and intellectual environment.
cons: As a grad student, one has to deal with constantly stressful life, lack of work-life balance, mental health issues but the good thing is that there are plenty of resources to help everyone from students to professors to employees.

pros: BU offers excellent benefits and professional development opportunities. The individuals who work with international students care about the students they are working with and attempt to work across departments to help those students be successful.
cons: The university as a whole has not worked very conscientiously towards providing services to assist international students succeed at the university. In the past, it seems that the response was accept students now, worry about services later. Now these students are floundering, and the university is not doing a very good job of assisting.

pros:
Members of some faculties are very good researcher in their field so you can work in reputable labs.

Average compensation but good health care package including vision and dental. You can use the facilities of Boston Medical Center.

Tuition remission is available for yourself or the family of the employee

If you are international, they can apply J1/H1 visa for oyu. Pretty effective International SCholar Office.

Very good location.
cons:
Research Associates are supported by the grants so it's a contractual job. You have to write your own grants to work here continuously otherwise it's a short-term (1-3 years) position.

Parking is very expensive, commuting on green line can be dreadful.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Boston, MA
pros:
BU provides a good working environment and a lot of good resources. I work in the photonics center, and the shared labs are great to work with. Other universities bill for usage in shared labs, but the ability to do research here with out worrying about the project budget is great.
The School is well known, and has a good network for finding future jobs.
cons: BU is located in a very expensive area, and the graduate student pay is similar to the national average which makes it very low for Boston.

review_title: It's not bad. It's not great.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Boston, MA
pros: You will meet some great co-workers you can commiserate with. Working with students is one of the most fulfilling jobs you can have.  The job is a great transitional job.
cons: "Transitional" is the keyword.  For your own personal and professional growth, you might have to find a different place to work. Bureaucracy is a slow grind, almost deliberately so. One must constantly remember that BU is a big incumbent business and not the spry start  up we want it to be.

review_title: Get a degree or use it as a stepping stone...
pros: Great tuition remission benefits & lots of ways to apply it. Quality educational programs & faculty. Like anywhere, there are some wonderful people doing great work.
cons: Pay is not on par with other comparable universities, strong anti-union sentiment among upper level management, very little investment in quality performance planning and review system such that reviews are very ad hoc. Some offices pretty dysfunctional. Administrative culture at BU overly image-driven, more concerned with PR than getting things done well.

review_title: Academic Research position right after graduation from BU ENG
pros:
Great people all around.

BU is in a great location, right near Kenmore square, so there are great food and afterwork hang out options.

Researching at BU lets you collaborate with people at the top of their fields through BU, MIT, and Harvard.
cons:
BU is big (the 4th largest employer in Boston) so working there does come with the headaches of dealing with such a giant organization. 

Once a month paychecks can be a pain for those just learning how to budget and academic researcher salaries aren't exactly the most generous in the world...

review_title: BU has real people working for it
pros: All you need is the right boss! Throughout the university there's all kinds of red tape to deal with, true, but if you're in the right office under the supervision of a good manager it doesn't matter. All of the red tape can go flying right out the window! Especially if you're working for a department that has a reasonable budget, which can depend a lot on the department chair and how smooth that person is in meetings. So if your department chair gets your department a good budget and you have a boss who can act like a real person you're all set.
cons: Well, all of the red tape, like I mentioned above.

pros: Great environment and educational rationale. Very helpful to students from all perspectives. Challenging, competitive, a perfect match for anyone that is willing to perform highly.
cons: Grade deflation is probably the biggest disadvantage of Boston University. Students have to struggle more than necessary to receive a mediocre grade, which in truth they deserve. It depends on the character of each person, but many give up because mediocre students are reflected by extremely bad grades.

pros: Good support for research at higher levels of administration. Development staff assistance with locating grants. Some protection from excessive service and teaching.
cons: Extreme lack of understanding of tenure track vs clinical track responsibilities and performance measures fosters a competitive and resentful work environment. Only certain types of research and scholarly work are supported despite hiring faculty who already have a research program. Promises made in offer letters are not fulfilled. Bitterness between faculty leads to undermining and sabotage. Resources are inconsistently made available to faculty.

review_title: Not a bad place to get a Masters
pros: AS a theatre student there are a large number of opportunities in the area to practice your craft and to make a decent wage doing so. Any one who is not afraid of handwork and dedication will do well here. Classes only meet once a week allowing a good bit of time for projects and homework to be completed and the professors are more than willing to meet you in their office to help you out when you are struggling.
cons: The hours are long, the work is hard, and often the Huntington is just plain in the way.

pros: Amazing opportunities to collaborate with talented people, a universal commitment to social justice, excellent benefits, a clear salary structure. Terrific leadership at the hospital. This has been my dream job.
cons: Less clear promotions criteria - as with many universities, the guidelines say there is no minimum number of publications, but you always seem to have "not quite enough." Hard for folks with clinical responsibilities to get promoted on the unmodified track. Typical difficult hospital-med school relationship which impacts the ability to have grant collaborators from different schools.

review_title: Decent employment for student workers, but wouldn't stay past graduation.
job_title: IT Support- Desktop Services in Boston, MA
pros: Flexible schedule for student employees, and supervisors are understanding and accommodating when schoolwork and exams take priority. Time off was easy to obtain and I did not have to find someone to cover my shift. Training was weak, badly organized, and often at least a month into the new semester. I received most of my training informally during shifts with coworkers who had been there longer. I had great coworkers.
cons: Office politics, gross preferential treatment for well-connected employees. There is not much room for growth. Some coworkers don't stick to policy and others do, causing client confusion and dissatisfaction when you don't give them special treatment.

review_title: RA opportunity for master of Economics student
pros: This is the place that economic department offers relevant research experience to master economics students on campus. And you can get some payment to compensate your tuition fee.
cons: Though the jobs are offered by IED, in fact,  the research assistant job that master students get are to work for PhD students from economics department. All the mentors are PhD students in senior years who want assistant to help their research project or papers. The attractiveness of work varies within mentors. Some get more programming work while others may do very boring data work. The time schedule also varies depending on who is your mentor.

review_title: Overall great environment with good benefits, but lower pay
pros: BU is a flexible, somewhat relaxed work environment with good benefits. It has a good reputation and a clear mission.
cons: There is no established process for pay raises. Promotions are rare unless you apply for a new position. Employee turnover is high. BU is a non-profit, so the pay is less than at a comparable company. The finances are not always as efficiently managed as they could be, probably because the organization is not focused on profit.

pros: The benefits are excellent, especially the tuition remission and the retirement plans. Additionally there is trainining available to help you improve your skill set.
cons: There is a heavy emphasis on degrees not quality of work when determing pay increases and promotions. This can be frustrating when you bust your butt and someone gets better raise beause they have more degrees, yet are lazy.

pros: decent work life balance, good benefits including vacation and time off.  Some room for growth if you end up in the right places.  Free tuition for BU course
cons: Leave alot for middle management.  Upper Execs and lower level employees feel comfortable handing off their work.  Central Administrative offices seem over worked and unwilling to help and or change.  health care has gotten much worse over the last 2 to 3 years

pros: BU offers it's employees a good quality of life, great product in category, and good benefits. Part of those good benefits include the option to continue your education, virtually free. The environment overall is friendly and not terribly stressful.
cons: BU is behind even the rest of the education community in it's pay offerings. They may have a hard time keeping good talent if this continues to be the case. There doesn't appear to be room for career advancement within departments.

review_title: Satisfying, Great People, Good Benefits, Comfortable work/life balance
job_title: Senior Programs Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: BU has great benefits, tuition remission, medical, retirement, time off.  Lots of vacation and sick time given, along with school holidays.
cons: Petty Politics can sometimes be an issue.  Pay is not great, but BU pays in benefits.  Stability can also mean boredom, especially on the administrative side of BU.

pros: A great environment, a lot going on, and great connections to a diverse and skilled group of people. They provide excellent employee benefits, especially as it relates to professional development. I have taken advantage of the free workshops and classes they offer about computer programming, business management skills, and a shole host of other
cons: It can be stressful at times. The schedule is structured around an academic calendar, which can be a bit annoying if you aren't a student or engaged with the academic side of things.

pros: The Tuition Remission benefit is the best thing about working at BU. You get 4 credits free and then 4 more credits at 90% off each academic year. Also it's pretty easy to transfer between departments.
cons:
The leadership in the University is oblivious and disconnected.

The beaurocracy of working at this institution is unbelievable. There is not an easy way to navigate any system. HR, Sourcing & Procurement, etc.

Performance is not rewarded at all. It's all about longevity here. So essentially you have faculty and staff that have been there forever but that do not contribute in any meaningful way.

pros: I absolutely love everyone in my office and thoroughly enjoy being around the people I work with.   Benefits are standard for higher education...which means they're pretty much great.
cons: The pay really is terrible, especially in comparison to other universities in the area. My same job in another school offers approximately 35% more in salary. My specific job can get pretty monotonous, and management is occasionally very annoying to deal with.

pros: Lots of smart and driven people in a non-competitive environment. The research groups are all very strong in their respective specialties.
cons: Upon being accepted, the physics department promises a lot of opportunities in getting accepted in the various research groups. In reality, the professors can be very pick and non-transparent when it comes to letting people know if they have a chance.

review_title: Enjoy the ebb and flow with the semesters
job_title: Assistant to the Dean in Etterbeek
pros:
I've worked in both the corporate side and academic side of the university. This review is for my current position on the academic side:

- The tuition remission benefits are fantastic. If you do grad-level courses, be wary of the classes counting as taxable income, but the benefit is still very much worth taking advantage of
- Working as an assistant to a Dean means you come into contact with people from all across the university. You get to meet a wide variety of interesting people and get to look behind the curtain to see how the university operates. 
-  I am fortunate to have a fantastic Dean as my boss- so far all of the Deans I've met at BU are genuinely nice people. He treats me with respect and values my education. He allows me to take classes during my work days and trusts me to make up the time on my own. 
- The Dean travels a lot and therefore folks in this position might have periods of quietness where they can get some work done at their own pace, followed by periods where the Dean is present and a lot of projects get catalyzed and things get busier. Overall the workload is very manageable
- Working with academics really spurs my intellectual curiosity. I'm always learning
cons:
- On the flip side of tuition remission being an awesome benefit, it can greatly reduce your paycheck by counting grad classes as taxable income. You get a fair amount back in your tax return but it makes the summer and fall months particularly difficult, especially with the HCOL in Boston
- Faculty are great, but organizing them can be difficult. Some folks are better with email than others. There is a lot of follow-up that needs to be done and you need to take extra initiative to get things organized properly
- Pay increases are pretty much maxed out at ~3-3.5% even if your reviews are glowing. It's higher education, so the pay generally isn't as high as in industry. But the tuition benefits help offset this con.
- If your school is small, you will be leaned on for more than traditional assistant duties. If you like to learn, this isn't much of a con, but it can be easy to let yourself get task-saturated by wearing too many hats. Also, you don't really get compensated more for that extra work unless you work overtime.
- It is difficult to move up as an assistant and stay in your

pros: I enjoyed the researchers that made up our department, and the many ways to get together with everyone through seminars, colloquiums, and other groups.
cons: Many of the great people left due to issues getting tenure or better offers elsewhere.  BU drove away the best of them.

pros: There were a lot of pros, particularly the salary was competitive, there is a strong union presence and you get additional paid days of for holiday closures.
cons: The commute into the city if you are living outside of it is definitely a con.  Opportunity for growth in my particular department was also minimal, which led to my resignation.

job_title: Desktop Services Specialist II in Boston, MA
pros: Great benefits, very friendly work environment, more relaxed winters and summers. This job allows you to form a very close rapport with clients, and still have a strong team backing you up.
cons: Too relaxed winters and summers. Sometimes less focused because of the size of the entity. Some locations that you can be placed at will feel a bit more remote.

review_title: As a researcher (i.e., non-faculty) you have a lot of freedom but you also have no job security.
pros: Boston is a great city, and BU is centrally located for easy access to downtown or to outlying boroughs.  The benefits are pretty good (healthcare + 403b matching).
cons: Students everywhere (maybe a pro for some).  BU itself does not value the position of research scientist, and so the bureaucracy will make your life more difficult than it needs to be for no good reason.

review_title: Enjoy working for Boston University overall, though there are some aspects that could be improved
pros: The benefits are amazing.  BU will help with employee tuition costs from day 1 of working full time and will help with family after some time commitment to BU has been met.
cons: There is some tension between different groups if employees that doesn't necessariliy play out well.  This primarily shows itself between groups having different levels of educations necessary for the position held.

review_title: Good benefits but management is terrible, with anecdotal exceptions
job_title: Senior Associate Director in Boston, MA
pros: Most staff care about what they do. Benefits are great, especially tuition remission and health insurance.
cons: Managers get no training or guidance in management or leadership. Some are great because they happened to get good mentorship, but there is nothing in place to ensure that managers & directors are anything other than good worker bees, so that's what most of them are.

review_title: Highest paid hospital RA in Boston?
pros:
Fair-to-good entry level compensation compared to every other Research Assistant salary I have seen online and heard through word of mouth at Boston Hospitals. I started at $20/hr (with no experience) within 6 months got made a full time employee and got a raise to $21/hr after a year and a half. 

I have a friend who is a Research Assistant II at BGW and they make significantly less than this, which is sad.

Good benefits:
-Tuition remission to BU excluding class fees which end up being around ($75-$250) depending on which courses you take. 
-Good retirement matching (although I foolishly never took advantage of this)
cons:
-HR is slow as molasses
-HR Training felt like a waste of time. When asked specific questions, participants are directed to "double check with someone in the department" or "check  online" It was basically a four hour overview of information that can be found online.  
-Classes available for tuition remission at BU can be spotty/limited depending on what you want to learn and are not consistent every year (EX: Taking med school prereqs and working full time is difficult. BU does a pretty weak job of offering night courses consistently during the academic year, and forget about taking night Physics/Chem/Orgo/Bio classes during summer through BU. There aren't any.)

pros: Students are great, some coworkers can be a lot of fun.
cons: The WORST pay in the industry...at least I can't imagine anyone going lower. Horrible management in my current position...I've never experienced such a level of micro-management or lack of trust in any other facet of my career, including in my previous position at BU. HR is clueless and messed with my pay for the first 4-5 months on the job, I can't take advantage of the education "benefit" because there are still fees to pay and taxes added on, so I'd essentially be living at the poverty level if I tried. Everything moves exceptionally slowly, making changes requires 3-4 middle men approving things that have nothing to do with them, all the while our poor students are waiting on answers that could ultimately have a very strong influence on their academic career and/or financial circumstances.

review_title: Evolving Culture, BU moving towards becoming a great place to work
pros: The benefits are good (paid time off is generous).  Depending on the office, the work schedule is manageable and expectations are reasonable. There is opportunity to be part of changing culture if you embrace it and ability to maintain work/life balance.
cons: slow moving.  Unlike other universities, does not seem to be as much of an "academic culture" among administrative employees.  The organization is not very nimble or fast moving, so it can be frustrating when trying to implement change.

review_title: Many great projects and faculty, but overly bureaucratic and unclear leadership
pros: Big university = diversity of opportunities & ideas, 17 schools, students from all around the world
cons: Big university = BUREAUCRACY! Too much emphasis on form over function, process over substance, money over mission. Inaccessible senior leadership. Very hierarchical structure means smart young employees with good ideas are rarely heard or used well.

pros: Research in advance topics with world-class facilities and with excellent faculty members. Boston is a very nice city to live and has some good industrial job opportunities around. It has a large student population.
cons: Boston is an expensive city to live. Postdoc career is an uncertain stage in the career of many. Salary is not up to the Ph. D. qualification.

review_title: BU is awesome. Engineering is NOT!
pros: BU has excellent benefits. 4 weeks vacation plus intercession. 11 holidays. Staff can take courses for free.  Social atmosphere, friendly people
cons: Engineering needs help. It's unorganized, old fashioned, policies aren't clear or they change every semester. Departments are not connected, people do what they want for the time being, and forget about the rest of the year.  Staff are overloaded with work, not enough resources.

review_title: Great Benefits, Decent Pay, but Monolithic and slow.
pros:
Amazing benefits: matching 403b, health, dental. 
Classes are nearly free (90% off after taxes, for 2 classes/semester).
Environment and culture can vary greatly. In small departments, can be very personal and fun. In large ones you can get pretty lost.
cons: This place has so many employees that it takes forever to get buy-in to do much of anything. I spend more time getting buy-in than I do getting things done.

pros: If on campus, very nearby. Local and convenient. Plenty of opportunities to work or do research on campus if you really want. Employees can also take one free class with others at a reduced cost.
cons: Very monotonous and you feel like you're getting nowhere sometimes. The working environment has a lot of favoritism and it's very annoying to realize you do all this work, but only to lose a promotion to someone who knew the manager better.

review_title: Very good people... some policies need to be looked at.
pros: Everyone I have worked with is very good at what they do. It's a wonderful place to be. Very fast pace.
cons: Some polices that are in place are not the most efficient. A majority of the support staff are extremely underpaid for the amount of work they do. Most times 2 to 3 people could do the work load expected of one support staff member.

pros: Questrom IT is run by very knowledgeable people, and they are great to work with. They are interested in your development as much as they are in the work you are doing.
cons: Like any other student jobs, the pay is very low. It comes with the knowledge that you are working for the school, but it's not absurd by any means.

pros: BU was a very stable place to work, I never felt like my job was in question. My department was also very flexible with time off and professional development.
cons: BU has all the same cons as any large institution, there's a long of red tape and it takes a very long time to do anything, but if you do it right you can still grow and learn.

review_title: Executive Leadership Center at the School of Management
pros: Overall, the University is a great place to work. Nice people, great benefits, down to earth, etc.
cons: Do not enter a job with the Executive Leadership Center at SMG The department is run incredibly poorly and every staff member there is treated like dirt due to the terrible, terrible leadership. Everyone at the School, and a large part of the University, know about the issues this department faces but no one will do anything about it. In addition to many other factors, there is constant turnover in the department but apparently that is not enough of a sign that something must be done with the leadership.

- Good compensation for grad students
- Focused course requirements
- Good resources / equipment

BU can be a great place for grad school. They don't have crazy requirements for the program, it can be very self-structured, and there's a lot of great resources.

I think graduate school in general is on a downhill trend right now. "Advising" tends to be pretty minimal, there's a lot of egos to deal with, and it doesn't always feel like there's someone out there trying to help you succeed.

review_title: Worked as a student tech for the physics department and did IT.
pros: Where I worked was a fantastic enviroment for learning electronics design, I can honestly say I learned more here than in my classes. In general, my impression that the part time jobs offered to students tend to be pretty good as far as part time employment for students goes.
cons: You won't get paid much as a student, but what were you expecting. The size of BU can also be dificult if you need something from another department as it's all rather bureacratic.

- can feels dragged down if you aren't used to being told "no" a lot

review_title: Great stepping stone till the next step disappeared

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Some of the benefits I had working at Boston University included close relationships with professors, lenient hours and deadlines, and reasonable compensation for an undergraduate.
cons: It was at some times unclear what the direction of our work was. The general purpose of the study lacked a clearly defined structure, which made research more difficult.

review_title: Solid place to do a postdoc in life sciences
pros:
-The life sciences facilities are relatively new and pretty nice
-Highly collaborative environment
-Salary and benefits are okay, comparable to other schools
-The postdoc office and professional development group is helpful in connecting people and for job searches
cons:
-There's not a lot of standardization or oversight over how professors run their labs, so some lab environments are much more difficult than others
-Perks are pretty minimal (no MBTA discount, gym membership is really costly)
-Location is alright, but commuting is tough when school is in session (crowded transit)

pros:
BU has an amazing benefits package including 4 weeks paid vaca with a 5th for intersession along with almost every holiday paid. Tuition remission is a phenominal perk and has ad's up to $8K to your total benefits package. Sick days accrue very quickly at over 1.5 a month and the overal ambiance of the CRC campus is especially pleseant.

Managment is usually very attentive and is willing to throw resources at a problem.
cons: Instituional change comes slow and is very political.

review_title: Good academic environment and good faculty. It's a good place to do your research if you can find the right person.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Work with knowledge and inspiring peers. The atmosphere is upbeat and inspiring. Most professors are extremely nice and friendly.
cons: As a engineering student, sometimes I find there are probably not enough seminars and conferences . Some professors are more focused on seeking funding instead of doing real research.

pros: Great time and really enjoyed the staff. The work was engaging and really beneficial if taken serious. Work with large accounting systems such as SAP.
cons: A bit repetitive. The work can get tiring, but it is important to push through. Just keep your head up and always keep a smile.

review_title: Great job for connections and getting an inside look at the mechanics of higher education
job_title: Program and operations assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Supportive, Organized, Good Perks, Involved
cons: Very routine, minimal team collaboration

pros: I worked in dining at Starbucks and loved being there. I had previous experience so I was promoted quickly. There's lots of opportunity for growth and a lot of time flexibility. My wages were great and I loved the bonus of free coffee. I made all my friends through working there and management is great.
cons: Extremely busy, not that it's the university's fault, but it can become very stressful. I overall loved it, but had plenty of times where I just wanted to give up.

review_title: Working at a university is great; find another one if you can.
pros: Location is great. Benefits and work schedule are great. Some smart people there.
cons: I worked in Information Services. Projects moved tediously slow. Some smart people there, but the different subgroups didn't get along. Because the benefits are so great, though, you have some people still there long after they should have moved on.

review_title: I had a great time working at BU, and would recommend it to anyone.
pros: Good insurance, opportunities for education, free tuition.  Fun city.  Great work environment, stimulating, fun.  It's very exciting to live in such a vibrant city.
cons: I can't think of any specific cons.  If you are an admin, it can be frustrating that other people get to do the "cool jobs" and you don't.  If that's the case.... take the opportunities to gain more training!  Boston con = expensive city!

job_title: Student Technical Consultant in Boston, MA
pros: The management is nice and works around your student schedule. You can easily notify them on days when you need to take off whether it be too much class work or sickness. It's above minimum wage in MA so great way to make pocket money for students. Obviously you won't get compensation as a student, but my supervisors who are full time staff are happy.
cons: Nothing in particular really. May have to live heavy items, but you are given a cart to transport stuff.

pros: Excellent tuition benefits and slightly above average stipend. The stipend is more than enough to live off of comfortably in Boston. The campus is centrally located and the faculty go above and beyond to assist ambitious students achieve their goals.
cons: Loose rules concerning the length limit of an individual PhD degree lead to misuse of graduate student labor by some faculty members.

review_title: Great place to work, endless opportunity

cons: Bureaucracy, constant workflow issues, some micromanagement, no system in place to grade the performance of those above you, overall pay is pretty low

pros: The team of other RAs was great. I really enjoyed working with my peers, and there is a lot of team work involved in the position. The free housing did not hurt either.
cons: ResLife is completely inflexible. They seem to be able to make as many mistakes as they want, but the minute an RA makes a mistake then all hell breaks loose. You constantly feel in fear of getting fired, which is not healthy.

review_title: Not the worst place to work but...

cons: No one gets fired, even for not doing their jobs. Very low pay comparative to other universities in the Boston area, good employees with talent and energy are not cultivated.  Little to no opportunity for growth.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA

cons: Culture and management depend highly on the division you are working in. Make sure you get a good sense of who you will be working with in your interview.

review_title: Happiness with a clinical research position depends greatly on the Principal Investigator

review_title: Working in academia is a whole different world

cons: The salary is on the low side in comparison with other employers in the area.  Working for such a large corporation there are many people and steps to go through before you can make any changes.

review_title: From 1998 to 2013 I worked as a senior security assistant in the student residences at Boston University.

review_title: Great place to learn some real world skills in school

review_title: Avoid Development and Alumni Relations at BU

review_title: Work with Smart, Motivated, and Successful Academics

review_title: Excellent research community driven to impact science and engineering through rigorous curricula and tech. development.

cons: This wasn't really the place for me, ultimately, so I don't think it's fair to state my beefs.  I would instead say that if you wanted to pursue a career in university administration, this is a place that (at the time) fostered people who wanted that.

review_title: About as much bureaucracy as you'd expect

review_title: It was a great place to get initial work experience while going part time As grad student.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA

review_title: A good place to work overall!

You have a large amount of control over the way you go about your research although your advisor will step in and micromanage if you are not making progress.  The work / life balance definitely leans more towards "life" than "work".  If you take summer courses you can finish in 1.5 years.  Overall the RA is a great opportunity to get a MS in engineering relatively quickly without accumulating large amounts of debt.
cons: As an RA you are at the mercy of your advisor.  Most RA's work more than 20 hours per week although I was lucky enough to keep my hours down.  Upon entering a research program many MS students hope to deliver some sort of a completed project, whether it be a piece of software or a hardware component.  The reality is that professors want students who are interested in learning for the sake of learning.  If you are motivated by delivering a completed project this is not the job for you. If you plan on working in industry after you graduate, a GTF position will give you a more marketable skillset.
